newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Cyprus says economy sound but must be careful.
newsitem.headline: Cyprus says economy sound but must be careful.

text.p: Cyprus has a sound economy compared to other small states but remains vulnerable to unexpected events, the island's finance minister said on Wednesday.
"Economically we are at a remarkable level compared to other small countries," Finance Minister Christodoulos Christodoulou told reporters.

"But we are still a small, open and very vulnerable economy and that must always be on our minds...we must not rest assured so we are not confronted with anything unexpected," he added, without elaborating.

Christodoulou, opening a three-day international conference on the effects of economic globalisation and regional integration on smaller countries, said larger countries had the upper hand defining trade trends.
"This meeting will give representatives of small countries the opportunity to define their problems and exchange views on ways for a common approach," said Christodoulou.
The conference, with 140 participants from 10 countries, is organised by the Cyprus Planning Bureau, a government-controlled think-tank.
Cyprus, predominantly a services economy, had a trade deficit of 1.114 billion pounds ($2.417 billion) in 1995, up 10.8 percent from 1,006.2 billion in 1994.
The European Union, which Cyprus has applied to join, is its main trading partner. It is due to start accession negotiations with the bloc in late 1997 or early 1998.

Dr. Ron Ayres, Principal Lecturer in Econonomics at the University of Greenwich in England, told the conference Cyprus and Malta, also a prospective E.U. member, have benefitted from a series of financial protocols 'but the trade consequences have been ambiguous'.
"Neither country has been constrained by a foreign exchange gap but this was largely because of the growth of tourism which was not subject to E.U. trade preferences," he said.

Theodoros Georgakopoulos, of the Athens University of Economic and Business, said Greece's accession carried a high cost from the point of view of the balance of payments. Imports increased more than exports and the Greek trade balance has severely deteriorated.

"Accession to the European Union implies far reaching institutional changes that can affect trade materially, (rather) than the simple realignment of tariffs, which is usually considered in customs union theory," he said. ($= 0.46 pounds)
